comments.commentBody: This is the system that's been in place for decades. It's the system Sanders accepted when he decided to run as a Democrat, instead of Socialist (his actual political party). Too late to start whining about the rules now.
Yes, bravo to Mrs. Clinton for buying a house in Chappaqua, a true melting pot.

Jane,

Really heartening to see your thinking expressed so well, which is pretty much how Sanders supporters think.

I see him as an elder, a learned elder, with real wisdom gained from having lived, experienced, and observed what has occurred in our once Democratic nation.

His character is impeccable, he exudes genuine concern, and his oft repeated statements describing the reality today, in our nation, is shocking, and any American who wants to hear, knows it to be true.

His solutions are simple, reasonable, and immediately doable, and contrary to what the Plutocratic Oligarchy, in total control of our government and our nation, want the uninformed to believe, the taxes necessary to accomplish his agenda, will be also reasonable, and the savings from not paying outrageous Insurance Premiums to Big Insurance will be thousands of dollars per family, after the expense of Medicare for All.

The "Free Public College tuition", is paid for by a tax on Wall Street profits and speculation, only fair since we gave them $800 plus billion to keep them solvent.

And the $15 dollar per hour minimum wage is a necessity, which corporate America, and yes, small business can afford.

Its time we got real here in our United States, and start caring for our people.

Beth,

"Again, Hillary puts her $$ where her mouth is, and has always actively supported other democrats."

If I was collecting the hundreds of millions of dollars, which Hillary and Bill collect, through some questionable methods, as in getting millions from Saudi Arabia, and arranging uranium sales from an American uranium mine to Russia, while Secretary of State, with Bill involved, when he is not otherwise engaged, I would cross many hands with silver, as she does, for several reasons, chief among them the desire to purchase cooperation, and of course "silence" ...
good one bruce..your comic retort is america at it worst and best....the best will win out...it always has...
good one bruce...better joke...chinese trying to corner what makes America  great...they still have not figured it out...despite the fact they are a great country...

Joel, perhaps you belong to one of the minority of Americans who do not tout American Exceptionalism on a daily basis.  If so, you wouldn't then be a hypocrite, who has a problem with a few Chinese feeling good about their feel-good stories, such as, double digit annual GDP growth for three decades and finally being strong enough to claim what have always belonged to them, etc.
Except that Chinese and Japanese are very different peoples.  Chinese are only keen on keeping what's theirs and Japanese have historically liked to take what's other's.
I think Xi might have read too much into the Monroe Doctrine.
He is a non-Chinese Signaporean in a Chinese dominated society, likely seconding the same inferiority complex mentality as those "small" southeast Asian countries that he is sympathizing with.
You may feel very differently if you had been sent to work in Russia instead.

Comparisons between urban concentrations are notoriously difficult and often flawed.  In Massachusetts, for example, the central city is obviously Boston.  When the Census Bureau then defines of the Boston Metropolitan Area, they are able to make quite precise calculations as to how far the Boston area extents outward because the real political jurisdictions in Massachusetts are town and cities, not counties, as is the rule outside New England.  So the Boston metro area is made up of the central city any and all cities , e.g. the city of Somerville, and towns, e.g. the town of Lexington, that are economically and socially integrated with Boston.  Elsewhere in America, the task is much more difficult. For example, a city such as Cleveland is an urban center of the metropolitan area inside the next political jurisdiction, which is Cuyahoga County and which includes residential areas which are clearly rural.  So it's apples and oranges. As in Lexington, MA versus North Randall, OH, both in metropolitan areas.

GjD is right!  Portland is full of low paying jobs, and the wages are going down, not up, for entry level.  Half a dozen of my friends over 50 never got a permanent job again, after losing jobs in the last seven years, as well as some in their 40's and 30's.  The unemployment rate is just the number of people collecting unemployment checks, folks.  So those of us who lost careers in this mess fell off the charts long ago.  Coders have their pick of jobs, but work next to middle aged contractors, some of whom are living thousands of miles from family for temp work.  Please stop reporting hot job growth here--most of it is in retail or coffee shops, and many people need more than one job to pay the bills!

"Cities where US Economy is Thriving"

A misleading headline... "Cities" is a plural... This article concentrates on one area... and tells us next to nothing about everywhere else...

I wish these articles would remember the rest of Colorado. Grand Junction for example. The local economy is nowhere near where Denver is, for a variety of reasons. Our leaders here have been trying for years to wean away from natural gas/coal extraction as an economic base, with some limited success. And let's not forget the vast acres of ranch land. I lived on the Front Range (defined Ft. Collins on the North to Colorado Springs on the South) for over 20 years. I'm happy to hear they're doing well, but there IS more to Colorado. Remember the rest of us.

I want to vote for the expansion but my property taxes soared 17% this year because of levies like move seattle. I have been a resident off and on since 1990 and I've rarely seen an initiative that voters didn't approve. How about that monorail, that worked out well.

That being said, I believe in Sound Transit. But the cost for us might be too high.
And don't forget to mention that the number of apartments and cluster townhouses have doubled in less than 6 years.  Destroying the community and the environment.

I think you need to go to Denver.  Light rail? Non-existent now and years and hundreds of billions out. They built their airport in the middle of nowhere.  The old airport was awesome and in town, but Denver follows most large cities.  Build it and they will come.

Ms. DiTomaso: Do you know who is pulling the strings for the whole superdelegate control of the Democratic Party? The Clintons. Do you know who is Chief of the Clinton Machine, aka the DNC? Debbie Wasserman Schultz. Did you hear Debbie Wasserman Schultz about a week ago give a talk in which she trashed the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (championed by Elizabeth Warren) and give ringing endorsement to "payday lenders", the predatory lending operators who primarily prey upon the poor and the working poor with outrageous usury! Then Obama turned around and made public endorsement for the re-election of Debbie Wasserman Schultzas DNC leader.  Does any of that sound anything like a real Democratic Party set of values? It does sound like the Clinton Cult of Personality and the Clinton Machine in full operation. And you know what? It reeks of insider trading of favors and advantages and wealth and power. Some of us are sick of it. I hope to God Bernie is telling the truth and not spouting slogans like the "hope and change" guy turned out to be doing. Lots of us, old and young, think he is and we want to give him a chance to make change and we want to work for that to happen. We are already working with him to make the "Democratic" Party seem a little more - oh, you know - democratic!  The Superdelegate system of the DNC and the Clintonites is as corrupt as it gets.

Basically someone previously one as a Democrat in one race or another doesn't mean they should have a right to have a significant influence on the Democratic process. It should be One Man One Vote not having an arbitrary 15% cushion for party elites. Voters in those general elections weren't told they were voting for Democrat party super-delegates and moreover not all of them are general election candidate winners- some of them are elder statesmen or distinguished members of the party that could have been elected for office 20 or more years ago e.g. Jimmy Carter still has a superdelegate slot.

It is undermocratic and there is no spin you can put on it. Candidates should win on pledged delegates alone not superdelegates and there is no justification of general election or not. In fact there are superdelegates who are just party bosses or senior members but never ran for general election office for any Congress or Senate seat or Governorship etc. Superdelegates are arbitrary and any one knowledgeable of their creation knows they were put in 80's to end the 'unelectable' ultra-progressive liberals like McGovern, Carter or Mondale from being selected and Democrats then losing the general election. It was made to suppress 'grassroots activists' as Debbie Wasserman Schultz said recently. Plain and simple.

The use of super-delegates for Clinton to win the nomination will lose her the election. Sanders voters, such as myself, will not support a candidate chosen by a rigged, anti-democratic process. The Dem elite are hereby put on notice.

The real issue with the Democratic Party nomination process is the superdelegate voters. The superdelegate vote allows the machinery of the party to hold a vast amount of power. If you want smart people to be spuerdelegates, then do it properly. Allow the people to vote for superdelegates that do not hold office snd are not part of the machinery. That is a far better electoral process.

Sanders should remain until the end. He may not get enough votes as far as the nomination is concerned, but he may beat Clinton straight up in national polls for having more support than Clinton. And that would show the horrible process that is in place for choosing the candidate for President.

Would help, but we already spend more per kid than any other country. So, its not money.  And teachers cannot be fired for incompetence,  so can't make improvements there. It's been determined by idiotic think tanks that disruptive kids should be coddled, not punished or removed from class, so there goes that fix.  Solution please?

articles like this should always be taken with a grain of salt

influx of highly educated (white) millennials
translation: gentrification, people can't afford housing, increasing inequality in resources and jobs for immigrants/minority residents/older workers

Boulder is a beautiful, economic booming college town
translation: Boulder has its fair share of rising economic & racial inequality. One example is that the city has recently passed a series of laws banning homeless people from public areas in order to cover up its rising homeless population (that is a result of rising inequality)

I'm afraid you are wrong, Mark.  Roe v Wade was a challenge to a Texas law that made it a crime to both obtain or attempt an abortion without the assent of a medical doctor on the grounds that the woman's life was at stake.  Defendant Wade was a Texas district attorney.

Gail, I usually absolutely adore you, but I admit this column and the comments here confuse me. What I don't see anyone saying is that, far from keeping their desire to punish women seeking abortions a secret, the pro-fetus crowd has several times used the power of the state to prosecute women who (having few other options in these states) self-induced. I believe at least one of these cases in recent years (involving a socially-isolated immigrant woman who bought an online herbal preparation meant to induce abortion), was in Indiana. There has been at least one related case involving a pregnant woman with active problems with substance abuse whose state tried to prosecute her for "child abuse," endangerment, or something similar for her addiction, rather that getting her help.

Recall that the rash of proposed state legislation at the last election cycle that would have legally defined life as beginning at conception had similar provisions. Admittedly these referenda did not prove popular with voters, but watching these events unfold over the past several years, it has never occurred to me that there was any real question (or even effort to deny) that the extreme Christian right absolutely believe that women seeking abortions should be punished.

A fetus is a potential person, and not a person until birth, that is the reasonable thinking line. Yes of course it's a human fetus w/ a soul from the moment of conception..... but not every seed can or will grow to maturity in life. Wild animals in nature will abort if they feel stressed/lack of food etc...humans are no different. Why fight a fact of life? Where is the understanding and compassion? Where is the support for individual choice?

Women's right leaders ought to have seen this, and used it. I suspect the very idea is so horrifying and "wrong" they couldn't and didn't even think it.

But if you kill a baby, that's murder. Someone who murders a baby ought to be punished. If you believe it is murder of a baby, it is obvious, the woman who kills her own baby, and the abortionist who helps her, are both committing a murder with careful forethought.

Even in the old days, we didn't do that. But in the old days, we did not think of it as a murder. We just said abortion was illegal, immoral, against God.

Now these guys are saying it isn't illegal for religious or moral reasons. They know they can't use those reasons to take back rights from women. So now they must say it is illegal because it is murder.

Well, murder with careful calculation and forethought is a very serious crime. They've backed themselves into this.

And Trump says it, "Well, yeah." That is a real service to the conversation, because he's right, and suddenly we al know he's right. That is where the anti-abortion argument goes, must go, with this reasoning.

Women's rights advocates ought to give Trump a big kiss for this one, before they kick him out the door. It is the biggest favor done for them in years.
So why not let him begin?

When the policy in question benefits plutocrats (e.g., TPP, bank deregulation), the Beltway establishment fights hard, goes for the gold, and does what it takes to get what they want. When the policy benefits ordinary working people, we get lectures from serious, responsible pundits about "incrementalism" and accepting "reality" (as they define it).
That was a 2015 poll. Things have shifted in 2016.

I can't think of one policy position Bernie Sanders has that I disagree with. However, I consider myself a political scientist and I have worked extensively in government and also worked for an office holder. I wish more Sanders supporters lived in the real world, because their expectations are wholly unrealistic, sometimes close to delusional. I think most Sanders supporters would agree that the US government has become a captive of elite special interests. But, a 2015 poll found that 50% of the electorate stated that they would not vote for a socialist. My question for Bernie's supporters is, how will Bernie, if he gets elected, be able to completely change this dynamic, even with a Democratic Congress? Probably one third of Democrats are tied to moneyed interests and to regain the House there will certainly be a number of Blue Dogs added.  A revolution is not going to happen, and just wishing by his supporters isn't enough. Look at how difficult it has been for Obama to make even modest reforms.  Whether you like it or not, change has to come incrementally and over time. Millenials are very liberal, but most voters over 40 aren't. It will take patient and slow change over the next generation to prepare the ground for the changes Bernie is proposing.

The truth is, all cities mentioned here are in the bubble economy - growth,  jobs (salaries vary widely), and county\city governments that cannot resist the ever growing\spending spree. Government is drunk with growing budgets and their plans for our communities are short term with no accountability.   Hold on Atlanta, Denver,  Seattle,  Portland,  etc.  Also, people bring with them their failed ideals of what the government is supposed to do. True for Reps and Dems.  Dems created sanctuary cities and Reps created blockades to women seeking an abortion.  Illegal immigrants are still illegal,  and abortion is legal, nationwide.
Except for poor women who can't afford to travel out of state for an abortion. It's the "size of bank account" exception that you mention.Otherwise, spot on.
We're already, sadly, having to go fund and kick start so girls and women can get across state lines, endure waiting periods... wouldn't putting that money to tuition be so much better?

GOP politico #1: Did you get the memo?
GOP politico #2: Which memo?
#1: The abortion one. Thanks to that big-mouth, Trump, we can't talk about arresting women who kill their fetuses anymore.
#2: So we can only arrest the doctor?
#1: Looks that way. Except maybe the lady doctors.
#2: That's no fun! What if there is no doctor? What if the abortion was self-induced?
#1: Arrest the coat-hanger.
Looks like the Republicans have put their foot in it now. The Party of Margaret Atwood (you mean that book was supposed to be "cautionary"?) now can't even get its act together on the issue they've been exploiting for decades for the purpose of winning support from an ever-dwindling minority of the electorate. At some point perhaps they'll begin to recognize that nothing about this issue can possibly work to their benefit. Even assuming they can elect a President who'll put a Supreme Court justice on the bench who'll overturn Roe once and for all, the issue will go back to the states and about half of them will continue to keep abortions legal and safe. And as long as even one state proceeds to do just that, American women who object to having Uncle Sam (or Uncle Donald or Uncle Ted) chain their legs to a pair of stirrups for nine months or so will find a way to visit that state and obtain the necessary procedure- even if one of the GOP exemptions don't apply (i.e., rape, incest, life of the mother and size of bank account/extent of political influence). Give it up, guys!
